citation.source: International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology

p.s: Description of Nonomuraea dietzii sp. nov.
Nonomuraea dietzii (diet'zi.i. N.L. gen. n. dietzii of Dietz, named in honour of the American microbiologist Alma Dietz)

The aerial mycelium develops different colours depending upon the ISP medium used: red/brown (ISP2), beige (ISP3), pink (ISP4 and ISP7), antique rose (ISP5) and white (ISP6); after approximately 14 d, the aerial hyphae develop masses of long spore chains, each containing up to 30 spores.
Spore chains may be stalked or may form clusters emerging directly from the agar.
Depending upon the ISP medium used, the nonfragmenting substrate mycelium is brown (ISP2), beige (ISP3), pink (ISP3, ISP 7) or rose (ISP5, ISP6) in colour.
DL-Diaminopimelic acid is the diagnostic amino acid of the peptidoglycan.
Cell hydrolysates contain galactose, glucose and ribose but not arabinose, xylose or rhamnose; madurose occurs in minor amounts.

The phospholipids include diphosphatidylglycerol, phosphatidylinositol, phosphatidylethanolamine, methyl-phosphatidylethanolamine and N-acetylglucosamine phospholipid; some unspecified glycolipids also occur.
The principal menaquinones are MK-9(III, VIII H4) and MK-9(H2) ; small amounts of MK-9 and MK-8(H4) occur.
The pattern of fatty acid methyl esters is composed mainly of iso- (iso-C14:0 and iso-C16:0) and 10-heptadecanoic (10-methyl-C17:0) branched fatty acids.
Smaller amounts of fatty acids are unbranched and saturated (C15:0;C17:0) and unsaturated fatty acids (cis9-C17:1) and 2-hydroxy (iso- C16:0 2-OH) fatty acid methyl esters can be found.
L-Arabinose, D-fructose, D-glucose, citrate and L-rhamnose are utilized, but not m-inositol, sucrose, xylose, D-mannose, D-raffinose or cellobiose.
Positive for gelatinase, urease, arginine dihydrolase, Î²-galactosidase and ornithine decarboxylase activities.
Positive for acetoin and H2S production; negative for tryptophan deaminase, lysine decarboxylase and indole production.

Shows no antibacterial effect on Micrococcus luteus, Streptococcus murinus, Bacillus subtilis, Staphylococcus aureus, Escherichia coli, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, Saccharomyces cerevisiae, Aspergillus niger or Candida albicans.
The isolation source is not recorded.
